awd_titl_txt: Preparing the Skilled Technical Workforce in Controlled Environment Agriculture
awd_abstract_narration:
The world's population is expected to more than double by 2050. As the productivity of traditional agriculture becomes compromised by urbanization and climate change, new methods of food production are needed. Controlled Environment Agriculture (CEA) is an emerging discipline that fosters year-round food production within local communities while reducing water use and transportation costs.  However, the industry has struggled to thrive due to a limited skilled technical workforce. The proposed project aims to meet the needs of the CEA industry by creating an interdisciplinary certificate for students enrolled in agriculture, automation and robotics, business and entrepreneurship, and/or computer technology associate degree programs. To do so, the project team will develop four new CEA courses and provide professional development to upskill faculty in the technologies that set CEA apart from traditional agriculture. This effort will be supported by an engaged industry board representing horticulture industries, extension specialists, and economic development experts. The project expects to develop a strong CEA curriculum that is responsive to workforce needs and builds on targeted outreach that includes underrepresented minorities, women, and rural high school students.  Consequently, the project can help ensure that the Nation maintains a well-prepared, diverse CEA workforce.

The project is designed to create a pipeline of well-educated technicians for the emerging CEA workforce.  A skilled technical workforce is critical to the success of the CEA industry and one expert has predicted the need for 100,000 workers in the next decade.  This project develop coursework in Aquaculture and Aquaponics, Automated and Smart Technologies, Integrated Facilities Management, and Project-based Study. These courses will use higher learning pedagogy that fosters interdisciplinary engagement of "ill-defined problems" to help students develop complex problem solving, higher-level thinking, and creative thinking skills. Project-based learning will expose students to real-world applications of smart-factory automation, growth of tilapia, and remote data collection and analysis. A virtual Internet of Things teaching platform utilizing webcasting equipment for online learning and remote access for data collection and monitoring of automated systems will give students a concrete advantage when entering the CEA workforce, where these technologies play a central role. The four new courses will be paired with agriculture classes already part of the Ivy Tech Community College system to create an interdisciplinary CEA Certificate. Professional development will be designed to upskill faculty who will teach these new and related courses at Ivy Tech Community College of Indiana, K-12 partners, and other community colleges across the country.  All project products will be disseminated through a project website and national conference presentations.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Project:  Preparing the Skilled Technical Workforce in Controlled Environment Agriculture

 

Final Report

 

 

 

 
   

 

 

Goals

The proposed project involves developing a Controlled Environment Agriculture (CEA) Certificate program for students in agriculture, automation and robotics, business and entrepreneurship, and computer technology associate degree programs. The project will create four courses for the certificate, provide professional development for faculty, and disseminate project products widely through a website and national conference presentations.

 

Accomplishments

Ivy Tech Community College transitioned the administration of the Green CEnsAtion project grant work to the Systems Office. Vearl Turnpaugh, Assistant Vice President for Curriculum, and Deb Pitzer, Dean of the School of Advanced Manufacturing, Engineering, and Applied Science, were key figures in leading the project. An external consultant, Claire Berger, was hired to provide guidance and mentorship. The consultant worked with the team to conduct research, develop achievable timeline goals, and guide Course Outline of Record development.

 

The Ivy Tech Community College formed a CEA taskforce during the 2023-2024 academic year to revise existing courses and develop new programs aligned with industry standards. The taskforce focused on the Terre Haute site, which had previously created an Industrial-scale CEA project. The taskforce made recommendations to the Agriculture Program Committee for changes to meet industry needs.

 

The AVP for Curriculum collaborated with the Terre Haute site to host the Ivy Tech CEA taskforce on November 7th, 2023. The taskforce included faculty and staff from three Ivy Tech sites, a project lead, an external consultant, and the AVP of Curriculum. They toured the Terre Haute facility and received insight into emerging CEA trends. The taskforce sat in on a presentation from an adjunct instructor who is a Subject Matter Expert in CEA, focusing on potential enhancements to the program. As a result, the Hydroculture certificate program adjustments were made, and new courses were developed to address industry needs. The program was restructured, increasing credit hours, and now provides students with stackable credentials and a clear pathway toward an Associate of Applied Science degree in Agriculture.

 

The key outcomes for this grant include the approval of changes to create and modify content for CEA programs, resulting in new degree pathways available for Fall 2024. These new degrees are within the Ivy Tech Catalog at CEA Technology Certificate, and CEA Technical Certificate. The work performed in Fort Wayne focused on program evaluation and the development of a Program Advisory Board.

 

The CEA taskforce visited the Terre Haute campus to review the large-scale CEA facilities and best practices. For professional development, faculty members pursuing the CEA Certificate will attend a Master Class in Aquaponics. Additionally, faculty members from various sites and programs participated at a Professional Development session at Purdue University, which included examples relevant to Technology in CEA coursework.

 

During the grant, the results of the activities were shared with Ivy Tech administrators at a meeting of the Ivy Tech State Board of Trustees. The AVP for Curriculum also presented information on the grant and its outcomes at the 2023 ATE PI grant and sought feedback from other CEA grant projects to steer conversations within the CEA taskforce.

 

Impacts

Ivy Tech has significantly updated the curriculum and courses for the CEA sector, focusing on increased enrollments in the Certificate and Technical Certificate programs. The program now features a better balance between Hydroponics and Aquaponics, incorporates new automated technologies in the first-year coursework, and has changed the degree structures to be more project-based. These changes will significantly improve student outcomes and better prepare candidates for working in highly automated CEA environments.

 

Students in other programs can now take new agriculture coursework and earn credits. These credits can be used in programs like Industrial Technology, Electronics and Computer Technology, and Precision Agriculture. CEA offers project-based learning opportunities for lighting, HVAC, water, and soil. This fosters teamwork in real-world scenarios.

 

The Fort Wayne campus recently hired an Agriculture program chair to lead the implementation of the Agriculture program and CEA pathway program.

 

CEA can help reduce food insecurity and minimize the use of herbicides, pesticides, and fertilizers. It allows for better monitoring and precise chemical application, resulting in less environmental contamination.

 

Changes in approach and reason for change:

The grant proposed that the new courses be placed in an interdisciplinary degree; however, after discussions with the Agriculture Program's Curriculum Committee, we placed the courses in the Agriculture Program as this was a better fit for the CEA content. Two new certificates were added: the CEA Technology Certificate and the CEA Technology Technical Certificate, which then flow into the AAS in Agriculture.

 

Problems or delays and plans to resolve them:

During the grant, personnel changes, PI and CoPI, and some SMEs left the college. These changes delayed the courses' reaching the proper people on the curriculum committee to give feedback and eventually approve them.
